questions.text: A patient had complaints of pain while passing stools. On examination, there was an opening adjacent to the anal canal. What is the 'gold standard' imaging modality?
questions.solution:
This is a case of Anal fistula.

Anal fistulae typically arise from infections of anal glands, leading to abscesses and subsequent discharge.

Classification: Park's classification categorizes fistulae as:

  • Trans-sphincteric
  • Intersphincteric
  • Suprasphincteric
  • Extrasphincteric

Imaging:

  • MRI: Preferred method; shows high signal fistulae against lower signal sphincter and fat. Effective for detecting abscesses and supralevator collections.
  • Endosonography: Useful for visualizing tracks within the sphincter and identifying internal openings.

Clinical Importance: Preoperative MRI helps reduce recurrence rates in complex cases.

Reference: Grainger and Allison's Diagnostic Radiology, A Textbook of Medical Imaging, seventh edition, Page number:596

questions.text: A patient presents with abdominal pain, constipation and increased urination, has history of renal calculi and psychiatric disorder. Which of the following is useful in diagnosing the condition?
questions.solution:
A typical history of "bones, stones, groans and psychic moans" is suggestive of Primary hyperparathyroidism.

Primary Hyperparathyroidism (HPT)

  • Hypercalcemia Causes:
    • Increased intestinal absorption of calcium
    • Increased bone turnover
    • Increased renal tubular resorption of calcium
  • Symptoms:
    • Tiredness, lethargy
    • Polyuria, anorexia, nausea
    • Bone pain, renal complications
  • Common Complications:
    • Nephrolithiasis (most common)
    • Hypertension
    • Peptic ulcers, pancreatitis
    • Psychiatric disorders

Imaging Techniques for Parathyroid Adenomas

  • Main Techniques:
    • High-resolution Ultrasound (US)
    • 99mTc Sestamibi Scintigraphy: Preferred for detecting solitary adenomas.

Fig. Sestamibi scan of Parathyroids

  • Nuclear Medicine Subtraction Imaging:
    • Combines thallium-201 and technetium-99m for improved localization of abnormal parathyroid glands.
    • Thallium-201 accumulates in high blood flow tissues; technetium-99m primarily in the thyroid.

Clinical Investigation of Primary HPT

  • Commonly Used Modalities:
    • Combination of US, 99mTc sestamibi, and parathyroid CT (4D CT).
  • Causes of Primary HPT:
    • Solitary parathyroid adenoma (80%)
    • Parathyroid hyperplasia (10-15%)
    • Multiple adenomas (2-3%)
    • Parathyroid malignancy (~1%)
  • US Findings: Well-defined hypoechoic mass typically located posterior or inferior to the thyroid.

Advancements in Imaging

  • 4D CT:
    • Useful for detecting ectopic parathyroid glands and differentiating between similar-looking structures (e.g., thyroid nodules vs. parathyroid adenomas).

Reference: Grainger and Allison's Diagnostic Radiology, A Textbook of Medical Imaging, seventh edition, Page number:1635

questions.text: A cancer patient is undergoing Radiotherapy. The radiotherapy is given in such a way that it is modified according to the shape of tumor. What is this type of radiotherapy called?
questions.solution:
Stereotactic Body Radiotherapy (SBRT)

  • Three-Dimensional Radiation Delivery: SBRT differs from traditional radiotherapy by distributing radiation beams in three dimensions, allowing for more precise targeting of tumors while minimizing exposure to surrounding healthy tissues.
  • Equipment: SBRT can be delivered using a modified standard linear accelerator or specialized machines like CyberKnife. These systems are designed to enhance accuracy and precision during treatment.
  • Applications:
    • Intracranial Tumors: SBRT is particularly effective for treating brain tumors where precision is crucial.
    • Extracranial Lesions: It is also used for selected small tumors outside the brain, such as those in the lung and prostate, as well as for small solitary metastases.
  • Treatment Approach: The precision of SBRT allows for the administration of high doses of radiation in a limited number of treatment sessions, often referred to as ultra-hypofractionation. Doses per fraction can reach up to 20 Gy or more, significantly enhancing the effectiveness of treatment while reducing the total number of sessions needed.
  • Advantages: The main benefits of SBRT include its ability to deliver high doses with pinpoint accuracy, leading to improved tumor control rates and reduced side effects compared to conventional radiotherapy, which typically involves lower doses over a larger number of fractions.

A: Hyperfractionated Radiotherapy

  • Definition: Hyperfractionated radiotherapy involves delivering smaller doses of radiation (fractions) more than once a day, typically twice daily, with each dose being lower than the standard daily dose.
  • Rationale:
    • This approach aims to deliver a higher total dose over the course of treatment without increasing the risk of late side effects.
    • It takes advantage of the fact that tumor cells might be more susceptible to lower doses given more frequently, while normal tissues may better repair between doses.
  • Use Cases:
    • Commonly used in head and neck cancers, lung cancer, and certain brain tumors.
  • Advantages:
    • Potentially improved local control of tumors by exploiting the different repair capacities of normal and cancerous cells.
  • Disadvantages:
    • More demanding schedule for patients and healthcare providers.
    • Increased risk of acute side effects due to higher overall doses.

B. Hypofractionated Radiotherapy

  • Definition: Hypofractionated radiotherapy involves delivering higher doses of radiation per fraction, but with fewer treatment sessions overall.
  • Rationale:
    • It aims to reduce the overall number of sessions, making the treatment course shorter.
    • This can be beneficial for patients in terms of convenience and reduced healthcare costs.
    • It leverages the higher doses per session to potentially cause greater tumor cell death.
  • Use Cases:
    • Widely used in the treatment of prostate cancer, breast cancer, and lung cancer.
    • Also utilized in palliative settings, where symptom relief and shorter treatment times are prioritized.
  • Advantages:
    • Shorter overall treatment duration, which is more convenient for patients.
    • May be effective for certain types of tumors that are more responsive to higher doses per session.
  • Disadvantages:
    • Increased risk of acute and late side effects if normal tissues cannot repair the damage from higher per-session doses.
    • Requires precise targeting to avoid damage to surrounding healthy tissue.

C. Accelerated Radiotherapy

  • Definition: Accelerated radiotherapy aims to shorten the overall treatment time by increasing the number of fractions per week, potentially even delivering more than one session per day (similar to hyperfractionation but with standard doses).
  • Rationale:
    • The goal is to reduce the time for tumor regrowth during treatment, as rapidly dividing tumor cells might proliferate between long treatment breaks.
    • This strategy targets fast-growing tumors that might otherwise continue to divide and repopulate during standard treatment schedules.
  • Use Cases:
    • Often used in head and neck cancers, lung cancer, and other rapidly proliferating tumors.
  • Advantages:
    • Reduced risk of tumor repopulation during the treatment course.
    • Potentially better tumor control, especially for fast-growing cancers.
  • Disadvantages:
    • Higher risk of acute toxicity due to increased treatment frequency and shorter recovery times for normal tissues.
    • Can be challenging for patients due to the increased intensity of the treatment schedule.

Reference: Grainger and Allison's Diagnostic Radiology, A Textbook of Medical Imaging, seventh edition, Page number:1738

questions.text: A 60 yr patient on bed rest since 10 days develops sudden onset breathlessness and chest pain. CXR done in the patient was normal. What is the best investigation in this patient?
questions.solution:
Given the patient's risk factors and symptoms, a CT pulmonary angiography (CTPA) is indeed the standard examination to evaluate for pulmonary embolism (PE). It provides rapid and accurate imaging of the pulmonary arteries and can help confirm or rule out the presence of a thrombus. Additionally, it's important to assess other risk factors and consider clinical scoring systems, such as the Wells score, to further evaluate the likelihood of PE. If CTPA is not available or if the patient has contraindications, other options like a V/Q scan may be considered. Monitoring and management of DVT risk, such as anticoagulation or mechanical prophylaxis, is also crucial for bedridden patients.

Reference: Grainger and Allison's Diagnostic Radiology, A Textbook of Medical Imaging, seventh edition, Page number:397

questions.text: What is the investigation of choice for neuroendocrine tumor?
questions.solution:
Neuroendocrine tumors (NETs), previously known as APUDomas, encompass a diverse range of tumors arising from neuroendocrine cells throughout the body. They can be classified into functioning and non-functioning tumors, with varying clinical implications.

Imaging Characteristics:

  • CT Imaging:
    • Pancreatic NETs (pNETs) are typically well-circumscribed and hypervascular, showing significant enhancement on late arterial phase images.
    • However, non-functioning pNETs may not exhibit hypervascularity, making them more challenging to identify.

Nuclear Medicine:

  • Nuclear medicine studies play a crucial role in the management of NETs by helping to:
    • Identify the primary tumor.
    • Assess the presence of metastases.
    • Evaluate somatostatin receptor status, which is important for therapy planning.
  • Somatostatin Receptor Imaging:
    • Imaging techniques, such as octreotide scans, are based on the expression of somatostatin receptors commonly found in NETs.

Preferred Investigation:

  • PET-CT is considered the investigation of choice for NETs. This modality provides detailed information about the metabolic activity of tumors, helping to accurately locate primary lesions and metastases.

Reference: Grainger and Allison's Diagnostic Radiology, A Textbook of Medical Imaging, seventh edition, Page number:1641

questions.text: A patient met with Road Traffic accident, presents in unconscious state. BP is normal and a NCCT image obtained is given below likely diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
A biconvex or lenticular hyperdense lesion on NCCT scan as shown in the image is suggestive of Extradural Haemorrhage(EDH).

  • An EDH is a collection of blood between the calvaria and outer (periosteal) layer of the dura.
  • They are usually associated with a history of head trauma and frequently associated skull fracture. The source of bleeding is usually arterial, most commonly from a torn middle meningeal artery.
  • EDHs are biconvex in shape. Adherence of the periosteal dura to the inner calvaria explains this typical configuration.
  • As EDHs expand, they strip the dura away from the inner table of the skull, forming the classic lens-shaped hematoma.
  • Because the dura is especially tightly attached to sutures, EDHs in adults rarely cross suture lines (10% of EDHs in children do cross sutures, especially if a fracture traverses the suture or sutural diastasis is present).

B. Subdural haemorrhage(SDH) is concave shaped and blood is collected beneath dura and shows a crescentic shaped hyperdensity on NCCT.

C. Subarachnoid haemorrhage(SAH) is blood collection in the subarachnoid cisterns and shows a Star of death sign on NCCT.

D. Intraparenchymal bleed is blood within the brain parenchyma.

Reference: Osborn Brain, edition 2, page number:21

questions.text: Identify the investigation given below:
questions.solution:
This is an image of MR enteroclysis.

  • MRI offers excellent soft-tissue contrast and three-dimensional imaging, making it ideal for evaluating small bowel pathology.
  • It is a noninvasive technique that eliminates radiation exposure, making it particularly suitable for pediatric patients and for monitoring conditions like inflammatory bowel disease.

Preparation for MRI:

  • Bowel Distension: Adequate distension of the bowel is essential. This can be achieved through techniques like enterography or enteroclysis.
  • Contrast Agents: Using homogeneous intraluminal positive or negative contrast agents enhances visualization. Biphasic contrast agents that appear hyperintense on T2-weighted sequences and hypointense on T1-weighted sequences are preferred for optimal contrast between the bowel wall and lumen. Examples include:
    • Water
    • Mannitol
    • Locust bean gum
    • Low-dose barium
    • Manganese compounds
    • Polyethylene glycol

Imaging Techniques:

  • Dynamic Imaging: High temporal resolution imaging sequences are important to minimize bowel motion artifacts. Many MRI protocols now include cine sequences, which allow for real-time assessment of intestinal motility.
  • Cine Sequences: These are particularly useful for distinguishing between peristaltic narrowing and true strictures, as well as for assessing the severity of strictures.

Detection of Tumors:

  • Gadolinium-enhanced T1-weighted MRI with fat suppression has demonstrated greater sensitivity for detecting small tumors compared to CT.

Option A: Barium Meal Follow-through

  • Definition: A barium meal follow-through is a fluoroscopic imaging study where the patient ingests a barium sulfate contrast solution, which coats the lining of the esophagus, stomach, and small intestine to enhance X-ray imaging.
  • Procedure:
    • The patient drinks a barium suspension.
    • Serial X-ray images are taken at intervals as the barium travels through the digestive tract, highlighting the shape and structure of the small intestine.
    • The test usually takes 2-4 hours, depending on the time it takes for the barium to pass through the intestines.
  • Uses:
    • Evaluating structural abnormalities like strictures, diverticula, or tumors.
    • Diagnosing inflammatory bowel diseases (e.g., Crohn's disease).
    • Assessing small bowel motility.
  • Advantages:
    • Widely available and relatively low cost.
    • Provides a functional view of bowel motility.
  • Disadvantages:
    • Time-consuming and may be uncomfortable for patients.
    • Limited in detecting subtle mucosal changes and extraluminal pathology.
    • Exposure to ionizing radiation.

Option B: Enterography (MR Enterography and CT Enterography)

  • Definition: Enterography is a specialized imaging technique (either MRI or CT-based) that provides detailed images of the small intestine using oral contrast. It is used to visualize both the lumen and the surrounding structures.
    • MR Enterography (MRE): Uses magnetic resonance imaging without ionizing radiation.
    • CT Enterography (CTE): Uses computed tomography with ionizing radiation.
  • Procedure:
    • The patient drinks a large volume of a neutral oral contrast agent (e.g., water or low-density barium) to distend the small bowel.
    • For CT Enterography, an intravenous contrast agent is often administered to enhance vascular structures and detect inflammation.
    • For MR Enterography, IV gadolinium-based contrast may be used to enhance imaging.
  • Uses:
    • Excellent for assessing inflammatory bowel disease, particularly Crohn's disease.
    • Identifying small bowel tumors, strictures, fistulas, and abscesses.
    • Evaluating extraluminal structures and complications (e.g., mesenteric inflammation).
  • Advantages:
    • Superior soft tissue contrast and detailed evaluation of bowel wall and surrounding structures.
    • Non-invasive with excellent visualization of small bowel pathology.
    • MRE avoids ionizing radiation, making it safer for younger patients and repeated follow-ups.
  • Disadvantages:
    • CTE involves ionizing radiation, although less than traditional barium studies.
    • Requires patient cooperation and adequate preparation (e.g., fasting, oral contrast ingestion).
    • MRE may be time-consuming and less accessible compared to CT.
    • CTE might not detect subtle changes in early-stage diseases.

Option C: CT Enteroclysis

  • Definition: CT Enteroclysis is a more specialized form of CT imaging where a nasojejunal tube is used to directly instill contrast material into the small intestine, providing detailed images of the small bowel lumen and surrounding tissues.
  • Procedure:
    • A tube is placed through the nose into the jejunum (proximal small intestine) under fluoroscopic guidance.
    • A large volume of contrast (e.g., methylcellulose or water) is directly infused to distend the small bowel.
    • The patient undergoes a CT scan with intravenous contrast to capture detailed cross-sectional images.
  • Uses:
    • Detecting small bowel tumors, strictures, adhesions, and other abnormalities.
    • Evaluating unexplained gastrointestinal symptoms where other imaging modalities have been inconclusive.
    • Assessing obscure gastrointestinal bleeding.
  • Advantages:
    • Direct infusion of contrast results in uniform distension of the small bowel, allowing for better visualization of subtle lesions.
    • Higher sensitivity for detecting small bowel tumors and strictures compared to other techniques.
  • Disadvantages:
    • Invasive procedure requiring placement of a nasojejunal tube, which can be uncomfortable.
    • Involves exposure to ionizing radiation.
    • Limited availability and requires expertise.

Reference: Grainger and Allison's Diagnostic Radiology, A Textbook of Medical Imaging, seventh edition, Page number:533

questions.text: Where is the location of coin?
questions.solution:
• Tracheal foreign bodies will orient in the sagittal plane (e.g. -coins will look like flat radiopaque circles on lateral films) while esophageal foreign bodies will orient in the coronal plane (e.g. -coins will look like flat radiopaque circles on AP films).
  • Given Xray is a lateral view of the chest which is shows a foreign body in lateral profile. This is suggestive of foreign body within the esophagus. Next step would be to do an esophagoscopy and remove it.

Reference: Grainger and Allison's Diagnostic Radiology, A Textbook of Medical Imaging, seventh edition, Page number:1789

Positron emission tomography (PET) is a diagnostic imaging technique that provides functional information about metabolic processes, which can be either physiological or pathological.

Primary Radiotracer:

  • 18F-fluoro-2-deoxy-D-glucose (FDG): The most commonly used radiotracer in PET imaging. FDG is a glucose analogue, and its uptake in tissues is proportional to the metabolic activity related to glucose metabolism.

Mechanism of Action:

  • Cellular Uptake: FDG is transported into cells via GLUT (glucose transporter) proteins. Tumors typically show increased FDG uptake due to the upregulation of GLUT transporters compared to surrounding normal cells.
  • Metabolic Trapping: Once inside the tumor cell, FDG is phosphorylated by hexokinase to form FDG-6-phosphate. Unlike glucose-6-phosphate, FDG-6-phosphate cannot be metabolized further in glycolysis because it is not a substrate for glucose-6-phosphatase. This leads to the metabolic "trapping" of FDG-6-phosphate within the cell.

Clinical Applications:

  • Cancer Management: 18F-FDG-PET is a standard imaging modality for:
    • Initial staging of various cancers.
    • Restaging after treatment to assess response.
    • Monitoring the effectiveness of therapy over time.

Reference: Grainger and Allison's Diagnostic Radiology, A Textbook of Medical Imaging, seventh edition, Page number: 1643

questions.text: Identify the given IVP image:
questions.solution:
Given image of IVP shows adder head appearance of the ureters which is highly suggestive of ureterocele.

This occurs as there is a membrane between the ureteric opening and bladder and on giving contrast there is pooling of contrast at the lower end and contrast does not pass to the bladder, thus giving the adderhead appearance.


A. Tortuous and dilated ureter and calyces in Hydronephrosis


B. Staghorn calculi


C. Bladder calculus

Reference: Grainger and Allison's Diagnostic Radiology, A Textbook of Medical Imaging, seventh edition, Page number: 776

questions.text: Identify the X-ray view:
questions.solution:
This is an image of Caldwell(Occipitofrontal) view showing the frontal sinuses clearly.

The Caldwell view is a radiographic technique that involves taking a caudally angled posteroanterior (PA) projection of the skull. This positioning helps minimize radiation exposure to the orbits.

Clinical Uses:

  • Imaging of the Skull: It is often employed to evaluate the frontal bone and paranasal sinuses.
  • Facial Bones: This view can also be used to assess the facial bones, particularly in cases of trauma or sinus disease.

Technique:

  • The patient's forehead and nose are placed in contact with the imaging plate.
  • The x-ray beam is angled approximately 15 degrees caudally, entering at the nasion, which helps visualize the structures of interest while protecting sensitive areas like the eyes.

List of other Xray views:


Schuller view: The Schuller View is a radiographic technique used to evaluate the temporomandibular joint (TMJ) and mastoid air cells. The patient is positioned laterally with the central ray angled 25°-30° caudally, targeting the TMJ area. This view helps diagnose TMJ disorders, fractures, and mastoid pathologies, providing a detailed image of the joint and surrounding structures.


Fig. Water's view


Fig. Schuller view


Fig. Towne view

Reference: Grainger and Allison's Diagnostic Radiology, A Textbook of Medical Imaging, seventh edition Page number: 1610, Radiopaedia.org

questions.text: Diagnose the given pathology in the given on the barium image:
questions.solution:
• The given image shows corkscrew esophagus in a barium image which is suggestive of diffuse esophageal spasm.
  • It is seen due to tertiary contraction of the esophageal muscles.
  • This radiological appearance is also known as pseudodiverticula or curling phenomena which can also be seen with spastic achalsia.
  • On CT, circumferential wall thickening (5 to 15 mm) of the distal 5 cm of the oesophagus may be seen

D. Bird beak appearance in Achalasia cardia


D. Rat tail appearance of Esophageal Ca

Reference: Grainger and Allison's Diagnostic Radiology, A Textbook of Medical Imaging, seventh edition, Page number: 494

choices.text: Below and medial to trigone of bladder
Above the dome of the bladder

questions.text: Pt with history of recurrent UTI, the IVP image is given, identify the location of insertion of ureter arising from left superior pelvis?
questions.solution:
• The Weigert-Meyer law describes the relationship of the upper and lower renal moieties in duplicated collecting systems to their drainage inferiorly.
  • With duplex kidney and complete ureteral duplication, the upper renal and lower renal moieties are drained by separate ureters, each having its own ureteral orifice in the bladder.
  • Upper renal moiety ureter has ectopic insertion medial and inferior to the lower renal moiety ureter, and frequently ends in a ureterocele
  • Lower renal moiety ureter has orthotopic insertion lateral and superior to the upper renal moiety ureter, and vesicoureteral reflux can occur.

Reference: Grainger and Allison's Diagnostic Radiology, A Textbook of Medical Imaging, seventh edition, Page number: 776

An electron linear accelerator (LINAC) is a sophisticated device designed to accelerate electrons to high energies using guided electromagnetic waves. It plays a crucial role in radiation therapy, particularly in the treatment of cancer.

Functionality

  • Acceleration of Electrons:
    • The LINAC accelerates electrons through a series of waveguides, generating high-energy electrons suitable for therapeutic applications.
  • Production of X-rays:
    • X-rays are produced via bremsstrahlung radiation, which occurs when high-energy electrons are directed onto a target made of materials with high atomic numbers (e.g., tungsten or gold). This process involves the deceleration of electrons, resulting in the emission of X-rays.

Applications in Cancer Therapy

  • Electron Therapy:
    • High-energy electrons are effective for treating superficial tumors, as they can penetrate tissue to a limited depth, making them ideal for certain types of skin cancers and localized tumors.
  • X-ray Therapy:
    • X-rays generated from the bremsstrahlung process can penetrate deeper into tissues, allowing for the treatment of tumors located deeper within the body.

Benefits

  • Precision: LINACs allow for precise targeting of tumors while sparing surrounding healthy tissue, which is critical in minimizing side effects.
  • Versatility: The ability to deliver both electron and X-ray radiation makes LINACs versatile tools in radiation oncology, accommodating a wide range of treatment protocols.

Reference: Grainger and Allison's Diagnostic Radiology, A Textbook of Medical Imaging, seventh edition, Page number: 1641

questions.text: A 20 year old male presented with pain and swelling around wrist joint. There is no history of injury. X Ray taken from the patient is shown below, what is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Soap bubble appearance on wrist Xray is indicative of Giant cell tumour.

Giant cell tumors of bone, also known as osteoclastomas, are relatively common bone tumors and are usually benign. They typically arise from the metaphysis of long bones, extend into the epiphysis adjacent to the joint surface, and have a narrow zone of transition.

General radiographic features include:

  • A narrow zone of transition: a broader zone of transition is seen in more aggressive giant cell tumors
  • No surrounding sclerosis: 80-85%
  • Overlying cortex is thinned, expanded, or deficient
  • Periosteal reaction is only seen in 10-30% of cases
  • Soft tissue mass is not infrequent
  • A pathological fracture may be present
  • No matrix calcification/mineralization

A. Sunburst appearance and Codman triangle in Osteosarcoma


B. Cupping, splaying, fraying in Rickets


C. Dinnerfork deformity in Colle's fracture

Reference: Grainger and Allison's Diagnostic Radiology, A Textbook of Medical Imaging, seventh edition Page number: 1009
